inventory.commentary: Added idioms, regrouped senses, added senses, modified examples and commentary. ahouston

sense.name: unit of meaning or expression, as in language or mathematics
sense.commentary: TERM[+abstract][+unit][+meaning][+linguistic/+logical/+mathematical] a word or symbolic expression that designates a concept, sometimes a quantitative concept
sense.examples: He learned many medical terms. What is another term for 'pursue'? What is the minor term of this syllogism? This term drops out of the equation. These are polynomial terms. Sally uses too many slang terms.

sense.name: specified length of time
sense.examples: He has served two terms in the Senate. The fourth term of this school year will end on June 15th. The billing term is thirty days. Bob's brother is serving a prison term for armed robbery. In the long term, the sun will become a red giant.

sense.name: a condition or stipulation
sense.commentary: TERM[+relation][+condition][+specified][+contract/+settlement] (usually plural) a statement of what is required as part of an agreement
sense.examples: The contract set out the terms for the lease. The terms of the treaty were generous. What are the terms of this return policy? We didn't like the terms of the settlement.

sense.name: an endpoint in time
sense.commentary: TERM[+position][+temporal][+endpoint] an endpoint, usually of gestation
sense.examples: She had her baby before full term. The infant had low birth weight at term. How much will this bond be worth when it comes to term?

sense.name: a description or account of something
sense.commentary: TERM[+expression][+description] Note: always occurs in the plural, unlike sense 1
sense.examples: He described the experience in glowing terms. There are no terms to express our gratitude for your help. I objected to it in the strongest possible terms.

sense.name: a state of social reciprocity
sense.commentary: TERM[+state][+social][+reciprocity] Note: always occurs in the plural
sense.examples: The two nations are not on good terms with each other. He and I have been on excellent terms for years.

sense.name: boundary figure on statuary
sense.commentary: TERM[+physical][+figure][+boundary][+statuary] terminus, terminal figure - (architecture) a statue or a human bust or an animal carved out of the top of a square pillar
sense.examples: Terms were originally used as a boundary marker in ancient Rome. The new building had a beautifully carved term on each column.

sense.name: resolve or acknowledge something
sense.examples: Mary finally came to terms with her illness. The warlords have resisted coming to terms with the central government. The two parties are expected to come to terms outside the courtroom.

sense.name: with respect to, in relation to
sense.commentary: Idiom: in_terms_of Note: in terms of X -> in X terms 'in terms of housing' -> 'in housing terms'
sense.examples: Ted always thinks in terms of money when planning his vacations. Teenagers today are a big marketing segment in terms of buying power. The party has lost momentum in political terms. (with respect to politics)

sense.name: according to one's wishes
sense.examples: The young entrepreneur is now able to negotiate on his own terms. Those nations must reach a peace settlement on their own terms, not through outside mediation.
